title: EPIC: CI/CD & Quality Gates
description:
# Epic: CI/CD & Quality Gates

## Overview
Set up comprehensive CI/CD pipeline to ensure quality and enable confident deployments.

## Background & Reasoning
A project of this scope needs automated quality gates:
- Catch bugs before they reach users
- Verify installer actually works on real Ubuntu
- Ensure website builds correctly
- Maintain code quality standards

## CI Components

### 1. Code Quality
- ESLint for TypeScript/JavaScript
- Prettier for formatting
- shellcheck for bash scripts
- TypeScript type checking

### 2. Website Tests
- Unit tests for components
- Build verification
- Lighthouse CI for performance

### 3. Installer Tests
- Spin Ubuntu VM (GitHub Actions runner or cloud)
- Run full install.sh
- Execute acfs doctor
- Verify all tools present

### 4. Integration Tests
- Manifest parsing
- Generator outputs
- Doctor check coverage

## GitHub Actions Workflows

```yaml
# .github/workflows/ci.yml
- lint-and-type-check
- test-website
- test-installer-ubuntu-25
- shellcheck-scripts
```

## Success Criteria
- [ ] All PRs require passing CI
- [ ] Installer tested on real Ubuntu
- [ ] Website build verified
- [ ] shellcheck passes on all .sh files
- [ ] Coverage reports generated
- [ ] Deployment preview for PRs

## Considerations
- Keep CI fast (< 10 min for most checks)
- Installer test can be slower (separate workflow)
- Use caching aggressively
- Matrix test multiple Ubuntu versions
close_reason: Closed

title: Set up GitHub Actions for website CI
description:
# Task: Set up GitHub Actions for Website CI

## Description
Create GitHub Actions workflow for website quality gates.

## Workflow File
`.github/workflows/website.yml`

## Jobs

### 1. lint-and-typecheck
```yaml
- uses: oven-sh/setup-bun@v1
- run: bun install
- run: bun run lint
- run: bun run type-check
```

### 2. build
```yaml
- uses: oven-sh/setup-bun@v1
- run: bun install
- run: bun run build
```

### 3. test (if tests exist)
```yaml
- run: bun test
```

### 4. lighthouse (optional)
```yaml
- uses: treosh/lighthouse-ci-action@v10
  with:
    urls: |
      http://localhost:3000/
    uploadArtifacts: true
```

## Triggers
- Push to main
- Pull requests to main

## Caching
```yaml
- uses: actions/cache@v3
  with:
    path: ~/.bun/install/cache
    key: ${{ runner.os }}-bun-${{ hashFiles('**/bun.lock') }}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Runs on every PR
- [ ] Lint + typecheck required to pass
- [ ] Build verification
- [ ] Caching for speed
- [ ] Clear failure messages
close_reason: Created GitHub Actions workflow for website CI. Fixed barrel import issues causing SSG build failures by switching to direct component imports. All lint, type-check, and build steps now pass.

title: Set up GitHub Actions for installer testing
description:
# Task: Set up GitHub Actions for Installer Testing

## Description
Create GitHub Actions workflow that tests the installer on real Ubuntu.

## Workflow File
`.github/workflows/installer.yml`

## Jobs

### 1. shellcheck
Fast job that runs on every PR:
```yaml
- uses: ludeeus/action-shellcheck@master
  with:
    scandir: './scripts'
    additional_files: 'install.sh'
```

### 2. test-ubuntu-25
Full installer test (may be slow):
```yaml
runs-on: ubuntu-latest
container:
  image: ubuntu:25.04
steps:
  - uses: actions/checkout@v4
  - name: Run installer
    run: |
      bash install.sh --yes --mode vibe
  - name: Run doctor
    run: |
      su - ubuntu -c "acfs doctor"
  - name: Verify key tools
    run: |
      su - ubuntu -c "ntm --help"
      su - ubuntu -c "ubs --help"
      # ... etc
```

### 3. test-ubuntu-24
Same but on 24.04 LTS for compatibility.

## Triggers
- Push to main
- Pull requests touching install.sh or scripts/

## Matrix Testing
```yaml
strategy:
  matrix:
    ubuntu: ['24.04', '25.04']
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] shellcheck passes on all scripts
- [ ] Installer works on Ubuntu 24.04
- [ ] Installer works on Ubuntu 25.04
- [ ] All tools verified after install
- [ ] acfs doctor exits 0

title: EPIC: Onboarding TUI
description:
# Epic: Onboarding TUI

## Overview
Build the interactive `onboard` command that teaches users Linux basics and the ACFS workflow through hands-on missions.

## Background & Reasoning
Documentation fails beginners. Interactive learning succeeds. The onboard TUI:
- Teaches by doing, not reading
- Builds muscle memory for key commands
- Introduces tools progressively
- Can be re-run anytime as a refresher

## 7 Missions

### Mission 0: Welcome
- What you now have
- The VPS as playground (safe to break, just re-run ACFS)
- Overview of installed tools

### Mission 1: Linux Navigation
- pwd, ls, cd, mkdir, rm
- /home/ubuntu vs /data/projects
- Navigation shortcuts (dev, proj, p aliases)

### Mission 2: SSH & Persistence
- What SSH is
- Why tmux matters (connection drops, tmux lives)
- Basic attach/detach

### Mission 3: tmux Basics
- Create/attach/detach sessions
- Split panes
- Copy mode basics

### Mission 4: Agent Commands
- cc (Claude), cod (Codex), gmi (Gemini)
- First login flow
- `caam backup` right after login

### Mission 5: NTM Command Center
- ntm deps -v (verify)
- ntm tutorial
- ntm spawn demo --cc=2 --cod=1
- ntm send/broadcast

### Mission 6: NTM Command Palette
- Show vendored command_palette.md
- Searchable prompt list
- "Send to all agents" feature

### Mission 7: The Flywheel Loop
- Plan in Beads → bv
- Coordinate via Agent Mail
- Run agents via NTM
- Search via cass
- Build memory via cm
- Scan with ubs
- Optional guardrails via slb

## Success Criteria
- [ ] All 7 missions implemented
- [ ] Can be re-run safely anytime
- [ ] Works offline (except optional updates)
- [ ] Takes < 30 minutes to complete all
- [ ] User feels confident to start coding

## Technical Approach
- Shell script or simple Go/Rust binary
- Uses gum or similar for TUI elements
- Stores progress in ~/.acfs/onboard_progress.json
close_reason: All sub-tasks completed: 2bn.1 (onboard TUI shell script). Interactive menu with gum support, progress tracking, and completion markers implemented.

title: Set up bun workspaces for monorepo
description:
# Task: Set up Bun Workspaces

## Description
Configure bun workspaces in the root package.json to manage:
- apps/web (Next.js wizard website)
- packages/manifest (manifest utilities)
- packages/onboard (onboard TUI)

## Technical Details
Root package.json should include:
```json
{
  "workspaces": ["apps/*", "packages/*"]
}
```

Each workspace needs its own package.json with appropriate name/scripts.

## Reasoning
Bun workspaces allow:
- Shared dependencies across packages
- Single lockfile (bun.lock)
- Easy cross-package imports
- Consistent tooling

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Root package.json with workspaces config
- [ ] Each workspace has valid package.json
- [ ] `bun install` works from root
- [ ] Cross-package imports resolve correctly

## Dependencies
Depends on directory structure being created first.

title: EPIC: VPS Installer (install.sh)
description:
# Epic: VPS Installer (install.sh)

## Overview
Build the one-liner bash installer that transforms a fresh Ubuntu VPS into a fully-armed agentic coding environment.

## Background & Reasoning
This is the "magic moment" - the user pastes one command and everything happens. The installer must:
- Work when run as root (common VPS default)
- Work when run as ubuntu with sudo
- Be idempotent (safe to run twice)
- Handle connection drops and resume
- Log everything for debugging

## Design Philosophy
**Vibe Mode Default**: Passwordless sudo, agents with full permissions, minimal friction.
**Checkpointed Phases**: Each phase writes state so reruns skip completed work.
**Module Manifest**: Single source of truth (acfs.manifest.yaml) drives all installs.

## Installer Phases
1. Preflight + confirm OS (Ubuntu 24.04+ / 25.x)
2. Create/normalize `ubuntu` user + sudoers
3. Base packages (apt)
4. Shell (zsh + oh-my-zsh + p10k + plugins)
5. Dev toolchain (bun, uv, rust, go, tmux, rg, ast-grep)
6. Agent stack (claude/codex/gemini CLIs + aliases)
7. Flywheel stack (ntm, slb, ubs, cass, cm, bv, caam, mcp_agent_mail)
8. Post-install UX (onboard + doctor + summary)

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Fresh Ubuntu 25.x VPS → working environment in < 15 minutes
- [ ] Safe to run twice without breaking anything
- [ ] All 8 Dicklesworthstone tools installed and verified
- [ ] `acfs doctor` shows all green
- [ ] Logs available at /var/log/acfs/install.log

## Considerations
- Always prefer upstream installers when available
- Verify each tool after install
- Provide clear error messages with fix suggestions
- Support `--dry-run` for transparency
close_reason: All 12 sub-tasks completed. VPS installer fully modularized with libraries for: logging, OS detection, user normalization, shell setup, CLI tools, language runtimes, coding agents, Dicklesworthstone stack, cloud/database tools, smoke test, and canonical zshrc.

title: Create installer logging library (scripts/lib/logging.sh)
description:
# Task: Create Installer Logging Library

## Description
Build a reusable logging library for consistent installer output.

## Functions

```bash
log_step()    # [1/8] Step description (blue)
log_detail()  # Indented detail (gray)
log_success() # ✔ Success message (green)
log_warn()    # ⚠️ Warning message (yellow)
log_error()   # ✖ Error message (red)
log_debug()   # Only if ACFS_DEBUG=1
```

## Requirements
- All output to stderr (keep stdout clean)
- Support --quiet flag (suppress non-errors)
- Support --verbose flag (show debug)
- Timestamps in log file
- ANSI color codes with fallback

## Log File
Write all output to:
- `/var/log/acfs/install.log`
- `~/.acfs/logs/install.<timestamp>.log`

## Implementation

```bash
#!/bin/bash
# scripts/lib/logging.sh

ACFS_LOG_FILE="/var/log/acfs/install.log"
ACFS_QUIET="${ACFS_QUIET:-0}"
ACFS_VERBOSE="${ACFS_VERBOSE:-0}"

log_step() {
    local step="$1"
    local msg="$2"
    echo -e "\033[34m[$step] $msg\033[0m" >&2
    echo "[$(date -Iseconds)] STEP: $msg" >> "$ACFS_LOG_FILE"
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All log functions implemented
- [ ] Colors work in terminal
- [ ] --quiet suppresses output
- [ ] --verbose shows debug
- [ ] Log file written with timestamps
- [ ] Works when sourced by other scripts

title: Create OS detection library (scripts/lib/os_detect.sh)
description:
# Task: Create OS Detection Library

## Description
Build a library to detect and validate the target OS.

## Requirements
- Detect Ubuntu version (24.04, 25.x)
- Detect architecture (amd64, arm64)
- Fail gracefully on unsupported OS
- Provide useful error messages

## Functions

```bash
detect_os()          # Returns: ubuntu
detect_version()     # Returns: 25.04
detect_codename()    # Returns: plucky
detect_arch()        # Returns: amd64 or arm64
validate_os()        # Exit 1 if unsupported
```

## Supported Configurations
- Ubuntu 24.04 LTS (noble)
- Ubuntu 25.04 (plucky)
- Ubuntu 25.10 (future)
- Architectures: amd64, arm64

## Implementation

```bash
#!/bin/bash
# scripts/lib/os_detect.sh

detect_os() {
    if [[ -f /etc/os-release ]]; then
        . /etc/os-release
        echo "$ID"
    else
        echo "unknown"
    fi
}

validate_os() {
    local os=$(detect_os)
    local version=$(detect_version)
    
    if [[ "$os" != "ubuntu" ]]; then
        log_error "ACFS requires Ubuntu. Detected: $os"
        exit 1
    fi
    
    # Check version >= 24.04
    if [[ "${version%.*}" -lt 24 ]]; then
        log_error "ACFS requires Ubuntu 24.04 or later. Detected: $version"
        exit 1
    fi
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Correctly detects Ubuntu versions
- [ ] Detects arm64 vs amd64
- [ ] Clear error on unsupported OS
- [ ] Works on fresh Ubuntu VPS

title: Create main install.sh orchestrator
description:
# Task: Create Main install.sh Orchestrator

## Description
Build the main installer script that orchestrates all phases.

## Script Structure

```bash
#!/bin/bash
set -euo pipefail

# Parse arguments
parse_args() {
    while [[ $# -gt 0 ]]; do
        case $1 in
            --yes) ACFS_AUTO_APPROVE=1 ;;
            --mode) ACFS_MODE="$2"; shift ;;
            --dry-run) ACFS_DRY_RUN=1 ;;
            --quiet) ACFS_QUIET=1 ;;
            --verbose) ACFS_VERBOSE=1 ;;
            *) log_error "Unknown option: $1"; exit 1 ;;
        esac
        shift
    done
}

# Main phases
main() {
    log_step "0/8" "Preflight checks"
    source_libs
    validate_os
    
    log_step "1/8" "Setting up ubuntu user"
    ensure_ubuntu_user
    setup_passwordless_sudo
    
    log_step "2/8" "Creating workspace"
    create_workspace
    
    log_step "3/8" "Installing shell environment"
    install_zsh_environment
    
    log_step "4/8" "Installing languages"
    install_languages
    
    log_step "5/8" "Installing dev tools"
    install_dev_tools
    
    log_step "6/8" "Installing coding agents"
    install_agents
    
    log_step "7/8" "Installing Dicklesworthstone stack"
    install_stack
    
    log_step "8/8" "Final configuration"
    deploy_configs
    install_onboard
    
    print_completion_message
}

main "$@"
```

## Error Handling
- Trap errors with helpful message
- Log to file before exit
- Suggest running acfs doctor

## Checkpointing
- Write completed phases to ~/.acfs/state.json
- Skip completed phases on re-run
- Support --force to re-run all

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All 8 phases implemented
- [ ] Clean error handling
- [ ] Checkpointing works
- [ ] --dry-run mode
- [ ] Completion message with next steps
- [ ] Works as root or ubuntu

title: Add installer security verification
description:
# Task: Add Installer Security Verification

## Description
Make the curl|bash pattern more trustworthy.

## Features

### 1. Checksum Verification
Before running sub-installers, verify checksums:
```bash
verify_checksum() {
    local url="$1"
    local expected_sha256="$2"
    local content=$(curl -fsSL "$url")
    local actual=$(echo "$content" | sha256sum | cut -d' ' -f1)
    if [[ "$actual" != "$expected_sha256" ]]; then
        log_error "Checksum mismatch for $url"
        exit 1
    fi
    echo "$content"
}
```

### 2. HTTPS Enforcement
All URLs must be HTTPS. Fail on HTTP.

### 3. --print Mode
Show exactly what will be downloaded:
```bash
install.sh --print
# Outputs:
# Will download:
# - https://bun.sh/install (sha256: abc123...)
# - https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh (sha256: def456...)
# ...
```

### 4. Source Links
Website shows link to install.sh source on GitHub.

### 5. Changelog
What changed since last version.

## Checksums File
```yaml
# checksums.yaml
installers:
  bun: "abc123..."
  uv: "def456..."
  # etc
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Checksum verification for key installers
- [ ] HTTPS enforced
- [ ] --print mode works
- [ ] Website links to source
close_reason: Implemented security.sh with HTTPS enforcement, SHA256 checksum verification, --print/--verify/--update-checksums modes. Created checksums.yaml with hashes for 14 installers. Commit bc41158.

title: Implement acfs doctor command
description:
# Task: Implement acfs doctor Command

## Description
Build the diagnostic command that verifies the entire ACFS installation.

## Location
Install to: `~/.acfs/bin/acfs`
Subcommand: `acfs doctor`

## Output Format

```
ACFS Doctor v0.1.0
User: ubuntu ✅
Mode: vibe (passwordless sudo: enabled) ✅
OS: Ubuntu 25.x ✅
Workspace: /data/projects ✅

Shell
  PASS ✅ zsh installed (zsh 5.x)
  PASS ✅ oh-my-zsh installed
  ...

Summary: 34 passed, 0 failed, 1 warning
Next: run `onboard`
```

## Check Structure

Each check has:
- id: Stable identifier for website mapping
- label: Human-readable name
- status: pass | warn | fail
- details: Version or extra info
- fix: Command to fix (on failure)

## Implementation

```bash
#!/bin/bash

run_check() {
    local id="$1"
    local label="$2"
    local check_cmd="$3"
    local fix_cmd="$4"
    
    if eval "$check_cmd" &>/dev/null; then
        echo "PASS ✅ $label"
        echo "{\"id\":\"$id\",\"status\":\"pass\"}" >> "$JSON_OUTPUT"
    else
        echo "FAIL ❌ $label"
        echo "      Fix: $fix_cmd"
        echo "{\"id\":\"$id\",\"status\":\"fail\",\"fix\":\"$fix_cmd\"}" >> "$JSON_OUTPUT"
        ((FAIL_COUNT++))
    fi
}

# Run all checks
run_check "identity.user_is_ubuntu" "Logged in as ubuntu" \
    "[[ \$(whoami) == 'ubuntu' ]]" \
    "sudo -u ubuntu bash"
```

## JSON Mode
`acfs doctor --json` outputs:
```json
{
  "acfs_version": "0.1.0",
  "checks": [...],
  "summary": {"pass": 34, "warn": 1, "fail": 0}
}
```

## Exit Codes
- 0: All pass (warnings OK)
- 1: Any failure
- 2: Doctor crashed

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All ~40 checks implemented
- [ ] Stable check IDs
- [ ] --json mode works
- [ ] Correct exit codes
- [ ] Fix suggestions on failure
- [ ] Summary at end

description:
# Task: Create SSH Troubleshooting Guide

## Description
Comprehensive guide for common SSH connection failures.

## Location
- Website: Embedded in wizard step 6
- Installer: ~/.acfs/docs/ssh_troubleshooting.md

## Common Issues Covered

### Permission denied (publickey)
**Symptoms:** `Permission denied (publickey)`
**Causes:**
1. Wrong key file specified
2. Key not added to VPS
3. Wrong username

**Fixes:**
```bash
# Verify key exists
ls -la ~/.ssh/acfs_ed25519*

# Try with verbose output
ssh -v -i ~/.ssh/acfs_ed25519 ubuntu@IP
```

### Connection refused
**Symptoms:** `Connection refused`
**Causes:**
1. SSH service not running
2. Firewall blocking port 22
3. Wrong IP address

**Fixes:**
- Check IP is correct
- VPS provider may need firewall rule

### Connection timeout
**Symptoms:** `Connection timed out`
**Causes:**
1. Wrong IP
2. VPS not fully booted
3. Network issue

**Fixes:**
- Wait 2-3 minutes for VPS to boot
- Verify IP in provider dashboard

### Host key verification failed
**Symptoms:** `Host key verification failed`
**Causes:** 
- VPS was recreated with same IP
- Man-in-the-middle warning

**Fixes:**
```bash
ssh-keygen -R IP_ADDRESS
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All common issues documented
- [ ] Clear cause → fix structure
- [ ] Commands are copy-paste ready
- [ ] Integrated in website step 6
close_reason: Created comprehensive SSH troubleshooting guide at acfs/docs/ssh_troubleshooting.md covering all common issues

# Epic: Website Wizard MVP

## Overview
Build the step-by-step wizard website that guides beginners from "I have a laptop" to "paste the curl|bash command".

## Background & Reasoning
The wizard is the user's first touchpoint with ACFS. It must:
- Feel premium and trustworthy
- Never overwhelm with jargon
- Make every step feel achievable
- Handle both Mac and Windows users
- Guide through VPS provider selection

## Tech Stack
- Next.js 16 App Router
- Bun runtime
- Tailwind CSS + shadcn/ui
- Vercel hosting + Cloudflare caching

## Key Design Principles
1. **Single action per screen** - One button or one command
2. **Copy button on every command** - Reduce friction
3. **"I did it" checkbox** - Gates "Next" button
4. **Collapsible troubleshooting** - Don't clutter but be ready

## Success Criteria
- [ ] All 10 wizard steps implemented
- [ ] OS-aware command rendering
- [ ] Mobile responsive
- [ ] Lighthouse score > 90
- [ ] Works without JavaScript (progressive enhancement)

## Relationship to Project Goals
The wizard is the "front door" to ACFS. A confused or frustrated user at this stage will never reach the VPS installer. Excellence here directly enables the 10-minute promise.

description:
# Task: Implement Wizard Step 3 - Generate SSH Key

## Description
Guide users through generating an SSH key pair and copying their public key.

## Page Copy
**Title:** Create your SSH key (this is your "login key")
**Body:**
You're going to create a key pair. You will paste the **public key** into your VPS provider.

### Generate the key
**Mac:**
```bash
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "acfs" -f ~/.ssh/acfs_ed25519
```

**Windows (PowerShell):**
```powershell
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "acfs" -f $HOME\.ssh\acfs_ed25519
```

Press Enter twice when asked for a passphrase (leave it empty).

### Copy your public key
**Mac:**
```bash
cat ~/.ssh/acfs_ed25519.pub
```

**Windows:**
```powershell
type $HOME\.ssh\acfs_ed25519.pub
```

**Action:** Copy the entire output (starts with `ssh-ed25519 ...`)

## Technical Details
- Two CommandCard components (generate, copy)
- OS-aware commands
- Emphasize copying the .pub file

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Clear two-step process
- [ ] OS-specific commands shown
- [ ] Copy buttons on both commands
- [ ] "I copied my public key" checkbox
- [ ] Troubleshooting for common errors

## Description

- Step 5: Create VPS and attach SSH key

## Step 5: Create VPS + Attach SSH Key
**Title:** Create your VPS and add your SSH key
**Content:**
1. Select Ubuntu 25.x as the OS image
2. Find "SSH Keys" section
3. Paste your public key (the one you copied earlier)
4. Create the server
5. Copy the IP address shown

Checklist:
- [ ] Selected Ubuntu image
- [ ] Pasted my SSH public key
- [ ] Server created
- [ ] I have the IP address

## Step 6: SSH In
**Title:** Connect to your VPS
**Command (Mac):**
```bash
ssh -o StrictHostKeyChecking=accept-new -i ~/.ssh/acfs_ed25519 ubuntu@YOUR_IP
```

**Command (Windows):**
```powershell
ssh -o StrictHostKeyChecking=accept-new -i $HOME\.ssh\acfs_ed25519 ubuntu@YOUR_IP
```

**Note:** If `ubuntu@` fails, try `root@` instead.

## Step 7: Paste the ACFS One-Liner
**Title:** Paste the magic command
**Command:**
```bash
curl -fsSL "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Dicklesworthstone/agentic_coding_flywheel_setup/main/install.sh?$(date +%s)" | bash -s -- --yes --mode vibe
```

**What this will do:**
- Create/enforce ubuntu user with passwordless sudo
- Install your full toolchain (shell, languages, agents)
- Install the Dicklesworthstone stack (all 8 tools)
- End by telling you what to type next
